article.headline: The U.S. behaved like a âgangsterâ to ârobâ TikTok from China and Beijing has âno reasonâ to approve the deal: Chinese media
article.body: An agreement on the ownership of TikTokâs U.S. operations approved by Washington last weekend is a âdirty and underhanded trickâ based on âbullying and extortion,â state-owned English language newspaper China Daily wrote in an editorial on Wednesday. It went on to compare the U.S. administration to âa gangster forcing an unreasonable and unfair business deal on a legitimate company.â - The White House last weekend approved a deal that quickly showed the three signatory companies at odds over its interpretation. TikTokâs Chinese owner, ByteDance, said it would own 80% of a new TikTok Global entity, while Oracle and Walmart, its U.S. future partners, insisted instead that they will control the company. - Global Times, an English language version of the Communist Party newspaper Peopleâs Daily, also denounced the Trump-approved deal on Wednesday, proclaiming in a headline that China wouldnât âallow the U.S. to rob TikTok.â The paper also quoted an expert describing Oracleâs founder Larry Ellison as âdefinitely an anti-China person.â - ByteDance chose database software company Oracle ORCL, +0.42% Â and retailer Walmart WMT, +1.00% Â over technology giant Microsoft MSFT, +2.48% Â when it was forced by Washington to hand over its U.S. operations under the threat of an outright ban. The U.S. government balked at a first version of the deal that kept the Chinese in control of the popular videosharing app. - âEven if it means TikTok could be shut down complete in the U.S., China will not sit idle and allow the U.S. government to seize a Chinese asset so brazenly,â the Global Times warned. Read:China flexes its muscles in Hong Kong with arrest of pro-democracy media tycoon Jimmy Lai The outlook: It looks like the White House-sanctioned deal wasnât quite a deal after all. But it is still hard to tell whether the Chinese media editorials signal Beijingâs outright opposition to any form of agreement, or whether they just amount to a bit of saber-rattling before another compromise is found. However important it has become to the online lives of American and European teenagers, and to President Donald Trumpâs campaign against Chinese security threats, TikTok isnât seen by analysts as crucial to Beijingâs interests. And in any case, the dispute about its ownership must be placed in the overall context of the tense and deteriorating U.S.-China relations.
